title: A Multicenter, Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled, Dose-Finding Study to Evaluate the Safety, Tolerability, Pharmacokinetic and Pharmacodynamic Effects of Posiphen® in Subjects With Early Alzheimer's Disease (AD) or Early Parkinson's Disease (PD)
description_brief: Annovis is conducting a clinical study to investigate Posiphen in patients with Early Alzheimer's Disease (AD) and Early Parkinson's Disease (PD). Investigators are looking to recruit 68 patients in two parts of the study. In Part one of the study Investigators will recruit 14 AD and 14 PD patients who will either receive placebo (an inert pill which looks like the study drug) or the study drug Posiphen, both taken daily. In Part two of the study Investigators will recruit 40 PD patients who will receive different strengths of the study drug Posiphen taken daily. Patients will be required to come to the site for 3 face to face visits and have 4 phone calls, tests include but are not limited to, blood and CSF (spinal fluid) sampling, cognitive assessments, clinical examinations and laboratory safety tests. Primarily the Investigators are looking for the safety and tolerability of Posiphen, although Investigators will also evaluate the activity of Posiphen by a number of different biomarkers measuring pathway and target engagements.
description_detailed:
Part 1 is a study with 14 Early AD and 14 Early PD patients who are randomized to 80 mg of Posiphen or placebo. Participants will undergo a Screening Visit, provide informed consent and be evaluated for eligibility per the inclusion and exclusion criteria. If enrolled, participants will proceed to the randomized treatment portions of the study. Period 1 consists of first-time dosing in clinic with administration of 80 mg of Posiphen or Placebo. Period 2 consists of an at home dosing period of 25±2 days, with daily administration of 80 mg of Posiphen or Placebo. Period 3 will be comprised of a stay at the clinical research unit where the subject will undergo study procedures that include safety assessments (AE and concomitant medication monitoring, 12-lead ECGs, clinical laboratory testing, vital signs assessments, and physical examinations), the last dose of Posiphen or Placebo, and 6 hours of blood and CSF sampling. At the end of blood/CSF sampling, the subjects will need to stay for a minimum of 1 hour of observation but may stay if necessary for observation until the following day (e.g., if the subject has blood/CSF sampling on Day 25, he/she may stay for observation until Day 26). After all end-of-study procedures are complete, the subject will be discharged to home. A 24-hour follow-up call will occur to assess the participants current condition and if there are any additional adverse events to report.

After completion of Part 1 of the study, the plasma and CSF samples will be analyzed for the biomarkers to determine if changes are needed to the biomarkers to be measured in Part 2. Since the conduct of the study in Part 2 will be identical to the conduct of the study in Part 1, recruitment will continue uninterrupted. The only potential change between Part 1 and Part 2 are the biomarkers to be measured.

Part 2 is a study with 40 Early PD patients, 10 patients each who are randomized to one of 4 treatment conditions of Posiphen (5 mg, 10 mg, 20 mg, or 40 mg). Participants will undergo a Screening Visit, provide informed consent and be evaluated for eligibility per the inclusion and exclusion criteria. If enrolled, participants will proceed to the randomized treatment portions of the study. Period 1 consists of first-time dosing in clinic with administration of 5, 10, 20, or 40mg of Posiphen. Period 2 consists of an at home dosing period of 25±2 days, with daily administration of 5, 10, 20, or 40mg of Posiphen. Period 3 will be comprised of a stay at the clinical research unit where the subject will undergo study procedures that include safety assessments (AE and concomitant medication monitoring, 12-lead ECGs, clinical laboratory testing, vital signs assessments, and physical examinations), the last dose of Posiphen or Placebo, and 6 hours of blood and CSF sampling. At the end of blood/CSF sampling, the subject will need to stay for a minimum of 1 hour of observation but may stay if necessary for observation until the following day (e.g., if the subject has blood/CSF sampling on Day 25, he/she may stay for observation until Day 26). After all end-of-study procedures are complete, the subject will be discharged to home. A 24-hour follow-up call will occur to assess the participant's current condition and if there are any additional adverse events to report.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Abeta42/Abeta40 Ratio
outcomeMeasures.description: Biomarker related to neurotoxic protein cascade measured in patient sample

outcomeMeasures.title: Changes in Functional Impairment
outcomeMeasures.description: Functional impairment will be evaluated using the Clinical Dementia Rating (CDR) scale (Berg1988) for AD.

outcomeMeasures.title: Changes in Functional Impairment
outcomeMeasures.description: Functional impairment will be evaluated using the Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (MDS-UPDRS) scale (Goetz 2008) for those with PD.

outcomeMeasures.title: Changes in Cognition
outcomeMeasures.description: For both populations, the Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) scale (Folstein 1975) will be administered as a global measure of cognition.

outcomeMeasures.title: Changes in Cognition
outcomeMeasures.description: For both populations, the Coding subtest from the Weschler Adult Intelligence Scales, 4th edition (WAIS-IV) will serve as a sensitive measure of CNS dysfunction.

outcomeMeasures.title: Changes in Cognition
outcomeMeasures.description: The subjects with AD will also be administered the The Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale-Cognitive (ADAS-Cog) Subscale (Schafer 2012).

drug: Posiphen (ANVS401; also referred to in company materials as buntanetap) — oral small-molecule translational inhibitor that reduces APP and other pathogenic protein translation
explanation_target: Reason: The investigational drug Posiphen is an orally administered small molecule that inhibits translation of amyloid precursor protein (APP) (and reportedly other aggregating proteins such as α‑synuclein) by binding an iron‑responsive element in the APP mRNA, thereby lowering APP and Aβ production — a disease‑pathology directed mechanism. citeturn0search7turn0search5turn0search3

Act: The trial you supplied is a randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled, dose‑finding study in early AD and early PD assessing safety, tolerability, PK/PD and biomarker (pathway/target engagement) effects of Posiphen — consistent with testing a disease‑targeted small molecule rather than a symptomatic cognitive enhancer or an agent for neuropsychiatric symptoms. citeturn0search7turn0search2

Reflect: Given the known mechanism (translation inhibition of APP and reduction of Aβ) and the study endpoints (biomarkers of pathway/target engagement plus safety and dose finding), the trial best fits the 'disease‑targeted small molecule' category. Company literature also describes the compound as an oral small molecule translational inhibitor (ANVS401/Posiphen/buntanetap), confirming the small‑molecule classification. No evidence in the description indicates the primary intent is symptomatic cognitive enhancement only or treatment of neuropsychiatric symptoms. citeturn0search3turn0search1

Key sources used (web search results): Alzheimer’s Research & Therapy full text (2024) describing Posiphen mechanism and the multicenter dose study; PubMed/medRxiv publications and TRCI/Wiley preclinical work on Posiphen’s APP translational inhibition; Annovis Bio company pages describing ANVS401 (buntanetap/Posiphen) as an oral translational inhibitor. citeturn0search7turn0search0turn0search5turn0search3
explanation_agent: Reason: The investigational drug Posiphen / buntanetap is an orally active small‑molecule translational inhibitor that reduces translation of amyloid precursor protein (APP) and thereby lowers production of Aβ — a direct disease‑pathology directed mechanism targeting the amyloid pathway. citeturn0search2turn0search3

Act: The trial description (dose‑finding, PK/PD and biomarker/SILK assessments in early AD/PD) and the drug mechanism (APP translational inhibition) indicate the study is testing a disease‑targeted agent whose principal, specific molecular action is to reduce APP/Aβ production — best mapped to CADRO category A) Amyloid beta. citeturn0search6turn0search5

Reflect: Company and recent publications also report buntanetap/Posiphen can reduce translation of other aggregating proteins (tau, α‑synuclein, TDP‑43), which could justify a broader "multi‑target" or "proteostasis/proteinopathy" interpretation; however, the primary, specific mechanistic readouts and the clinical indication for AD emphasize APP/Aβ lowering, so the most specific CADRO classification is A) Amyloid beta. If one prioritized the drug platform claim of simultaneous inhibition of multiple neurotoxic proteins, R) Multi‑target or I) Proteostasis/Proteinopathies would be reasonable alternatives. citeturn0search0turn0search1

Key web sources used: Annovis Bio — Our Science / Mechanism pages (describing buntanetap/Posiphen as a translational inhibitor of APP and other aggregating proteins). citeturn0search0turn0search1; PubMed studies demonstrating Posiphen inhibits APP translation and lowers APP/Aβ in cells and animal models. citeturn0search3turn0search2; Alzheimer's Research & Therapy (full‑text multicenter SILK dose study) describing the early AD dose‑finding/SILK trial and biomarker modeling. citeturn0search6
